title: FirstFT: Goldman Sachs boosts pay for junior bankers
text:
Goldman Sachs has become the last of the big US investment banks to raise salaries for junior staff in response to complaints about burnout from new recruits caught in a dealmaking boom during the pandemic.

The issue of burnout among younger employees became particularly sensitive at Goldman after a group of first-year staff spoke out about the effects of gruelling hours on their mental health and led to a fierce internal debate about pay. 

Some top executives have argued that boosting junior salaries, which are fixed and cannot be easily reduced, could set a “dangerous precedent” and attract “mercenaries”, the Financial Times reported last month.

First-year analysts will now earn a base wage of $110,000, rising to $125,000 in their second year, according to people familiar with the decision. Those at the more senior associate rank will receive a boost to $150,000. The figures do not include annual bonuses, which can be multiples of salaries in buoyant years.

The increases mean Goldman will have one of the most generous starting pay packages in the industry, having previously paid junior bankers less than their peers, according to Wall Street Oasis, a website that tracks pay.

Five more stories in the news

1. Tencent imposes controls to tackle gaming addiction among children The Chinese tech giant has introduced new controls to limit the amount of time children spend playing its games after state media labelled the gaming industry “spiritual opium”. The new restrictions will initially only apply to its flagship title Honour of Kings.

2. Carbon offsets going up in smoke US forests that generate the carbon offsets bought by companies including BP and Microsoft are on fire as blazes rage in North America. Corporate net-zero emission pledges rely on such projects to compensate for the carbon dioxide they generate.

3. IMF warns on crypto as national currencies The multilateral lender has warned against using cryptocurrencies as legal tender as El Salvador prepares to become the first nation to allow bitcoin payments for everything from haircuts to taxes.

4. Amazon union vote should be rerun, says US labour board official A failed vote to unionise at an Amazon warehouse in Alabama should be rerun over concerns that the tech giant improperly influenced workers. “Amazon's behaviour throughout the election process was despicable,” said Stuart Appelbaum, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union.

5. Belarus opposition leader urges west to toughen sanctions Western nations need to tighten sanctions on Belarus to put pressure on President Alexander Lukashenko to restore democracy and end worsening repression, opposition leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya told the Financial Times, following the controversy surrounding Belarusian athlete Krystsina Tsimanouskaya.

Tokyo Olympics round-up

  • Simone Biles won a bronze medal in the balance beam, a week after taking herself out of several competitions to focus on her mental health. She earned her seventh career Olympic medal and is now tied with Shannon Miller for the highest tally in American gymnastics.

  • Karsten Warholm broke his own world record earlier today in the greatest men's 400-metre hurdles race ever run. The 25-year-old Norwegian finished in 45.94 seconds, smashing his previous record of 46.70 and becoming the first man to finish in under 46 seconds. American Rai Benjamin took silver.

  • New Zealand weightlifter Laurel Hubbard became the first openly transgender athlete to compete in an Olympics.

  • How have Russian athletes been winning medals even though Russia was banned from the Olympics? Murad Ahmed and Max Seddon explain. (FT, NPR)

Add ‘Tokyo Olympics' to myFT for all our coverage from the Games, and don't miss our “alternative medals table”.

Coronavirus digest

  • San Francisco and six Bay Area counties yesterday became the latest areas in the US to reinstate a universal mask mandate for indoor public places in an effort to contain the spread of the highly virulent Delta Covid-19 variant.

  • Officials in China now believe the main chain of transmission for the latest outbreak in the country originated from a contaminated aircraft that arrived from Russia on July 10. The number of cases rose to 83 today.

  • The IMF has agreed to a $650bn allocation of its special drawing rights to boost the pandemic finances of low and middle-income countries.

  • French pharmaceutical group Sanofi will acquire its partner Translate Bio for $3.2bn, as it makes a big bet on the future of mRNA as a transformative technology for vaccines and therapeutics.

Sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter and follow the latest developments on our live blog.

The day ahead

Special elections Coal lobbyist Mike Carey will be hoping the backing of former president Donald Trump will help secure him the Republican nomination in Ohio's 15th congressional district election today. In the state's 11th congressional district, the battle is between Democratic party progressive Nina Turner and centrist Shontel Brown.

Earnings round-up Chinese ecommerce giant Alibaba reports first-quarter fiscal 2022 earnings today following weeks of intense scrutiny by Chinese authorities. Lyft, the ride-hailing service, also reports results. Read the full list here.

Meng Wanzhou hearing The chief financial officer of Chinese tech giant Huawei will be back in a Canadian court today for a final round of hearings on her possible extradition to the US. (Straits Times)

Raisi takes power in Iran Iran's new president Ebrahim Raisi will be sworn in as the Islamic republic has been shaken by protests over water and electricity shortages and readies for talks over the 2015 nuclear deal.

What else we're reading

Is Joe Biden's presidency vulnerable to inflation? The US bounceback from the depths of the coronavirus crisis has been remarkably vigorous after Joe Biden approved $1,400 in direct payments to low and middle-income households and vaccinations spurred a quick lifting of restrictions and a burst of spending. The only blot of an otherwise encouraging picture: higher than expected inflation.

China's young ‘lie flat' on stress A trend among young Chinese to opt out of stressful jobs represents the antithesis of the development model that has delivered extraordinary growth over four decades. As youths put the “996” — 9am to 9pm, six days a week — work schedule on notice, Beijing is perturbed. (FT, NYT)

We should not be sanguine about a shrinking population The pandemic's impact on procreation may prove fleeting. But it has focused attention on the long-term decline in the number of babies women are having almost everywhere, writes Sarah O'Connor.

Welcome to the era of the activist accountant In an unexpected modern tale, activist accountants have become vital advocates towards standardising ESG risks, says editor at large for the US Gillian Tett, in this video.
